Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech and disregards the voices of regular citizens.
It creates a divide between politicians, journalists, and educators versus regular citizens in terms of who can spread information.
The internet is a democratic tool that empowers ordinary people, and this bill disadvantages them.
Excessive fines will lead to overly restrictive monitoring of speech by digital services.
The bill's scope includes true information deemed 'misleading', which undermines freedom of speech.
Industry codes could be used for anti-competitive practices, benefiting large digital services over smaller ones.
The bill applies extraterritorially, which could isolate Australia from the global internet community.
It contradicts principles of freedom of political communication and could lead to censorship of political viewpoints.
The bill imposes threats and intimidation on digital platform providers and users, reminiscent of oppressive regimes.
Notable Quotes: The internet is the most powerful democratic invention of our time, empowering ordinary people to have a voice.
It is impossible to accurately determine what is true or untrue.
The requirement to report and potentially 'dob-in' fellow citizens is reminiscent of oppressive regimes.
